     174             : 
     175             : /// Equivalent of a RefPtr<TextureSource>, that calls AddCompositableRef and
     176             : /// ReleaseCompositableRef in addition to the usual AddRef and Release.
     177             : ///
     178             : /// The semantoics of these CompositableTextureRefs are important because they
     179             : /// are used both as a synchronization/safety mechanism, and as an optimization
     180             : /// mechanism. They are also tricky and subtle because we use them in a very
     181             : /// implicit way (assigning to a CompositableTextureRef is less visible than
     182             : /// explicitly calling a method or whatnot).
     183             : /// It is Therefore important to be careful about the way we use this tool.
     184             : ///
     185             : /// CompositableTextureRef is a mechanism that lets us count how many compositables
     186             : /// are using a given texture (for TextureSource and TextureHost).
     187             : /// We use it to run specific code when a texture is not used anymore, and also
     188             : /// we trigger fast paths on some operations when we can see that the texture's
     189             : /// CompositableTextureRef counter is equal to 1 (the texture is not shared
     190             : /// between compositables).
     191             : /// This means that it is important to observe the following rules:
     192             : /// * CompositableHosts that receive UseTexture and similar messages *must* store
     193             : /// all of the TextureHosts they receive in CompositableTextureRef slots for as
     194             : /// long as they may be using them.
     195             : /// * CompositableHosts must store each texture in a *single* CompositableTextureRef
     196             : /// slot to ensure that the counter properly reflects how many compositables are
     197             : /// using the texture.
     198             : /// If a compositable needs to hold two references to a given texture (for example
     199             : /// to have a pointer to the current texture in a list of textures that may be
     200             : /// used), it can hold its extra references with RefPtr or whichever pointer type
     201             : /// makes sense.
     202             : template<typename T>
     203             : class CompositableTextureRef {
     204             : public:
     205           0 :   CompositableTextureRef() {}
     206             : 
     207           0 :   explicit CompositableTextureRef(const CompositableTextureRef& aOther)
     208           0 :   {
     209           0 :     *this = aOther;
     210           0 :   }
     211             : 
     212           0 :   explicit CompositableTextureRef(T* aOther)
     213           0 :   {
     214           0 :     *this = aOther;
     215           0 :   }
     216             : 
     217           0 :   ~CompositableTextureRef()
     218             :   {
     219           0 :     if (mRef) {
     220           0 :       mRef->ReleaseCompositableRef();
     221             :     }
     222           0 :   }
     223             : 
     224           0 :   CompositableTextureRef& operator=(const CompositableTextureRef& aOther)
     225             :   {
     226           0 :     if (aOther.get()) {
     227             :       aOther->AddCompositableRef();
     228             :     }
     229           0 :     if (mRef) {
     230           0 :       mRef->ReleaseCompositableRef();
     231             :     }
     232           0 :     mRef = aOther.get();
     233           0 :     return *this;
     234             :   }
     235             : 
     236           0 :   CompositableTextureRef& operator=(T* aOther)
     237             :   {
     238           0 :     if (aOther) {
     239           0 :       aOther->AddCompositableRef();
     240             :     }
     241           0 :     if (mRef) {
     242           0 :       mRef->ReleaseCompositableRef();
     243             :     }
     244           0 :     mRef = aOther;
     245           0 :     return *this;
     246             :   }
     247             : 
     248           0 :   T* get() const { return mRef; }
     249           0 :   operator T*() const { return mRef; }
     250           0 :   T* operator->() const { return mRef; }
     251             :   T& operator*() const { return *mRef; }
     252             : 
     253             : private:
     254             :   RefPtr<T> mRef;
     255             : };
     256             : 
     257             : typedef CompositableTextureRef<TextureSource> CompositableTextureSourceRef;
     258             : typedef CompositableTextureRef<TextureHost> CompositableTextureHostRef;

     333             : };
     334             : 
     335             : /**
     336             :  * TextureHost is a thin abstraction over texture data that need to be shared
     337             :  * between the content process and the compositor process. It is the
     338             :  * compositor-side half of a TextureClient/TextureHost pair. A corresponding
     339             :  * TextureClient lives on the content-side.
     340             :  *
     341             :  * TextureHost only knows how to deserialize or synchronize generic image data
     342             :  * (SurfaceDescriptor) and provide access to one or more TextureSource objects
     343             :  * (these provide the necessary APIs for compositor backends to composite the
     344             :  * image).
     345             :  *
     346             :  * A TextureHost implementation corresponds to one SurfaceDescriptor type, as
     347             :  * opposed to TextureSource that corresponds to device textures.
     348             :  * This means that for YCbCr planes, even though they are represented as
     349             :  * 3 textures internally (3 TextureSources), we use 1 TextureHost and not 3,
     350             :  * because the 3 planes are stored in the same buffer of shared memory, before
     351             :  * they are uploaded separately.
     352             :  *
     353             :  * There is always one and only one TextureHost per TextureClient, and the
     354             :  * TextureClient/Host pair only owns one buffer of image data through its
     355             :  * lifetime. This means that the lifetime of the underlying shared data
     356             :  * matches the lifetime of the TextureClient/Host pair. It also means
     357             :  * TextureClient/Host do not implement double buffering, which is the
     358             :  * reponsibility of the compositable (which would use two Texture pairs).
     359             :  *
     360             :  * The Lock/Unlock mecanism here mirrors Lock/Unlock in TextureClient.
     361             :  *
     362             :  */
     363             : class TextureHost
     364             :   : public AtomicRefCountedWithFinalize<TextureHost>
     365             : {
     366             :   /**
     367             :    * Called once, just before the destructor.
     368             :    *
     369             :    * Here goes the shut-down code that uses virtual methods.
     370             :    * Must only be called by Release().
     371             :    */
     372             :   void Finalize();
     373             : 
     374             :   friend class AtomicRefCountedWithFinalize<TextureHost>;

     377             :
